Description: Black glaze stemless pottery cup with convex body; mended from fragments; glazed save for underside of foot which has central dot; in the tondo, stamped palmettes linked by incised curves in a circular pattern; grooved half-ovals inside the circle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Spurlock Museum, University of Illinois. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published in S.U. Wisseman, CVA World Heritage Museum, College of Liberal Arts and Sciences Krannert Art Museum, College of Fine and Applied Arts I (USA 24), 1989, p. 54, pl. 63.7. Wisseman suggests an Apulian origin for the cup, citing as a comparison a cup in the Royal Ontario Museum, inv. 968.11.1 (Hayes, Greek and Italian Black-gloss Wares and Related Wares in the Royal Ontario Museum, 1984. Pp. 62/63, no. 103, with additional comparanda). However, the shape of the handles and the reasonably complex inside decoration clearly indicate an Athenian origin.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1517)
